G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to *G.L. c. 208, § 28*, “upon a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties, the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children if the modification is in the best interests of the children.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY JUDGMENT (Filed Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and related authorities)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the custody matters of the parties under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* (modification of judgments concerning custody and support of minor children) and *G.L. c. 215, § 6*.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody decisions. *See* **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Blixt v. Blixt**, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A modification is warranted where the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests. *See* **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns when a modification of an existing custody arrangement is warranted—specifically, that modification is appropriate when the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests. Mason v. Coleman is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on whether relocation should be allowed based on the children’s best interests in a joint physical custody context. The court affirms continued joint custody and denies removal; it does not articulate or apply a general standard for modification of custody orders based on a breakdown of the existing arrangement, so it does not support the cited modification proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court. … The judge … did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: A modification is warranted where the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests. *See* **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **Murray v. Super**, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The Murray opinion concerns a removal request and a child support modification, not a general standard for when custody/visitation arrangements may be modified. The court affirms denial of the mother’s removal-based modification because the move is not in the children’s best interests, but it does not articulate or apply a rule that a modification is warranted whenever the existing arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests. That broader proposition comes from Mason v. Coleman, not from Murray itself, so citing Murray for that general standard overstates its holding.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the real advantage to the mother does not align with the children’s best interests or the interests of the father… The judge did not err in finding that the proposed move would have clear and significant negative effects on the children and the father that were not outweighed by the benefits that would inure to the mother. That decision is supported by the record and the judge’s copious findings of fact; we accordingly discern no error. … The portion of the judgment dismissing the mother’s complaint for modification is affirmed.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts have consistently held that chronic school absenteeism, educational decline, and a parent’s unwillingness to cooperate on school matters may justify modification of custody. *See* **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal v. Maney does not deal with chronic absenteeism, educational decline, or a parent’s unwillingness to cooperate on school matters as grounds for modifying custody. Instead, the court reverses a change of custody, holding there was no material and substantial change in circumstances and that the relocation effort itself could not justify modification. The opinion focuses on relocation standards and the ‘real advantage’ test, not on school-related deficiencies as a basis for custody change, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker… The judgment modifying custody must be reversed.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Courts have consistently held that chronic school absenteeism, educational decline, and a parent’s unwillingness to cooperate on school matters may justify modification of custody. *See* **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale is a removal/relocation case, not a custody‑modification case, and it does not discuss chronic school absenteeism, educational decline, or a parent’s unwillingness to cooperate with school matters as grounds to change custody. The opinion focuses on how to evaluate a custodial parent’s request to move children out of state, emphasizing the best interests of the child and the well‑being of the custodial parent, not school‑related misconduct justifying modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law favors arrangements that ensure stability and educational continuity for children. *See* **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The court explicitly emphasizes that in custody determinations it is generally in the child’s best interests to preserve existing satisfactory arrangements and warns against disrupting a stable status quo. It characterizes stability and continuity with the current caregiver as of “enormous benefit” and directs judges to avoid unnecessary rearrangements of a child’s living situation. While the case is not about school moves per se, its reasoning clearly supports the broader proposition that Massachusetts law favors stability and continuity (including, by implication, educational continuity) for children.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law favors arrangements that ensure stability and educational continuity for children. *See* **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on custody, joint versus sole physical custody, and especially the removal (relocation) standard, emphasizing the ‘real advantage’ test and the best interests of the child. While it discusses whether the child’s quality of life will be improved and evaluates competing interests, it does not articulate any general Massachusetts policy preference for ‘stability and educational continuity’ as such. Any inference about stability or schooling is incidental to the relocation analysis rather than a clearly stated, general rule favoring stability and educational continuity.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)… and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: When joint legal custody is undermined by one parent’s failure to cooperate on significant issues, modification may be required to appoint one parent as final decision-maker in the child’s educational matters. *See* **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); **Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The case does not involve joint legal custody or modification of such an arrangement; instead, the court affirms an award of sole custody to the mother and explicitly rejects joint custody as inappropriate due to the parents’ inability to cooperate on major child‑rearing issues. While the opinion discusses that joint custody requires mutual ability to agree on major issues like education, it does not address appointing one parent as final decision-maker within a joint custody framework or modifying an existing joint legal custody order. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying joint legal custody to designate a final educational decision-maker.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, we agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary, in order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents… together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’ … [T]he judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: When joint legal custody is undermined by one parent’s failure to cooperate on significant issues, modification may be required to appoint one parent as final decision-maker in the child’s educational matters. *See* **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); **Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion deals with relocation and statutory custody rights of an unmarried mother under G. L. c. 209C, not with joint legal custody, lack of parental cooperation, or modification to appoint one parent as final educational decision‑maker. It neither articulates nor applies a standard about breaking joint legal custody where cooperation fails, so using Smith v. McDonald as authority for that proposition is inaccurate. Any reliance for that proposition must come from other cases, such as Rolde v. Rolde, not from this decision.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights."

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody decisions. *See* **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Blixt v. Blixt**, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of the grandparent visitation statute, G.L. c. 119, § 39D, not about custody determinations under G.L. c. 208, § 31. While the court notes that the ‘best interests of the child’ standard has long been used in Massachusetts for custody and visitation questions, it does not state that this standard governs all custody decisions, nor does it purport to interpret § 31. The proposition overreads Blixt, which only references ‘best interests’ generally and in the visitation context, not as an across-the-board rule for all custody matters.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation. This standard has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation and other issues relating to child welfare. The statute, however, uses the standard in a new context, and, based on the reasoning in the Troxel case, the standard, left unspecified, cannot survive a due process challenge.”
